sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The following section will help you become more familiar with the spacecmd command-line interface. This interface is available for SUSE Manager, Satellite and Spacewalk servers. spacecmd is written in Python and uses the XML-RPC API provided by the server.

itemizedlist.title: What can spacecmd do for me?

listitem.para: Manage almost all aspects of SUSE Manager from the command line with spacecmd
Tab completion is available for all commands
Single commands can be passed to spacecmd without entering the interactive shell (excellent for shell scripts)
May also be accessed and used as an interactive shell
Advanced search methods are available for finding specific systems, thus removing the need to create system groups (nevertheless groups are still recommended)
Complete functionality through the Spacewalk API. Almost all commands that can be executed from the WebUI can be performed via the spacecmd command-line

sect1.title: Configuring spacecmd
sect1.para: The following section provides configuration tips for spacecmd.

sect2.title: Setup Spacecmd Credentials
sect2.para: Normally spacecmd prompts you for a username and password each time you attempt to login to the interactive shell. Alternatively you can configure spacecmd with a credentials file to avoid this requirement.

step.para: Create a hidden spacecmd directory in your home directory and set permissions:
Create a config file in ~/.spacecmd/ and provide proper permissions:
Edit the config file and add the following configuration lines. (You can use either localhost or the FQDN of your SUSE Manager server):
Check connectivity by entering spacecmd as root:

sect2.title: spacecmd Quiet Mode
sect2.para: By default spacecmd prints server status messages during connection attempts. These messages can cause a lot of clutter when parsing system lists. The following alias will force spacecmd to use quiet mode thus preventing this behavior. Add the following line to your ~/.bashrc file:

sect1.title: spacecmd Command Reference
sect1.para: The following links provide descriptions for all documented spacecmd commands. Each command is grouped by the function prefix. Keep in mind that all commands may also be called using scripts and passed to spacecmd as stand-alone commands.

sect2.title: activationkey_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for use with activation keys.

listitem.para: Add child channels to an activation key.
Add configuration channels to an activation key.
listitem.screen:
usage: activationkey_addconfigchannels KEY <CHANNEL ...> [options]
options: -t add channels to the top of the list -b add channels to the bottom of the list

listitem.para: Add available entitlements to an activation key.

note.title: WebUI Name Change
note.para: In the WebUI entitlements are known as System Types. Nevertheless the spacecmd backend still utilizes the entitlements term. Therefore any scripts you may be using can remain unchanged.

listitem.para: Add existing groups to an activation key.
Add packages to an activation key.
Clone an existing activation key.
listitem.screen:
usage examples: activationkey_clone foo_key -c bar_key activationkey_clone foo_key1 foo_key2 -c prefix activationkey_clone foo_key -x "s/foo/bar" activationkey_clone foo_key1 foo_key2 -x "s/foo/bar"
options: -c CLONE_NAME : Name of the resulting key, treated as a prefix for multiple keys -x "s/foo/bar" : Optional regex replacement, replaces foo with bar in the clone description, base-channel label, child-channel labels, config-channel names

listitem.para: Create a new activation key.
listitem.screen:
usage: activationkey_create [options]
options: -n NAME -d DESCRIPTION -b BASE_CHANNEL -u set key as universal default -e [enterprise_entitled,virtualization_host]

listitem.para: Delete an existing activation key.
Show details of an existing activation key.
Check the difference between two activation keys.
Disable an existing activation key.
Disable configuration channel deployment for an existing activation key.
Enable an existing activation key.
Enable configuration channel deployment for an existing activation key.
Export activation key(s) to a JSON formatted file.
listitem.screen:
usage: activationkey_export [options] [<KEY> ...]
options: -f outfile.json : specify an output filename, defaults to <KEY>.json if exporting a single key, akeys.json for multiple keys, or akey_all.json if no KEY specified (export ALL)
Note : KEY list is optional, default is to export ALL keys

listitem.para: Import activation key(s) from JSON file(s)
List all existing activation keys.
List the base channel associated with an activation key.
List child channels associated with an activation key.
List configuration channels associated with an activation key.
List entitlements associated with an activation key.
List groups associated with an activation key
List packages associated with an activation key.
List systems registered with an activation key.
Remove child channels from an activation key.
Remove configuration channels from an activation key.
Remove entitlements from an activation key.
Remove groups from an activation key.
Remove packages from an activation key.
Set the base channel for an activation key.
Set the ranked order of configuration channels.

Set the contact method to use for systems registered with a specific key. (Use the XML-RPC API to access the latest contact methods.) The following contact methods are available for use with traditional spacecmd: ['default', 'ssh-push', 'ssh-push-tunnel']
Add a description for an activation key.
Set a specific key as the universal default.

warning.title: Universal Default Key
warning.para: Using a universal default key is not a Best Practice recommendation.

listitem.para: Set the usage limit of an activation key, can be a number or "unlimited".
listitem.screen: usage: activationkey_setbasechannel KEY <usage limit> usage: activationkey_setbasechannel KEY unlimited

tip.title: Usage Limits
tip.para: Usage limits are only applicable to traditionally managed systems. Currently usage limits do not apply to Salt or foreign managed systems.

sect2.title: api
sect2.para: The following API command and its options are available for calling the XML-RPC API directly. Calling the API directly allows you to use the latest features in SUSE Manager from the command-line using spacecmd as a wrapper for stand-alone commands or used from within scripts.

note.title: Use the api Command for Access to Latest Features
note.para: spacecmd is the traditional tool for spacewalk. It functions out of the box with SUSE Manager but you should know that latest features (eg. Salt) are often excluded from traditional spacecmd command-line tool. To gain access to the latest feature additions call api api.getApiCallList from within spacecmd to list all currently available API commands formatted in json. You can then call these commands directly.

listitem.para: Call XML-RPC API with arguments directly.
listitem.screen:
usage: api [options] API_STRING
options: -A, --args Arguments for the API other than session id in comma separated strings or JSON expression -F, --format Output format -o, --output Output file
examples: api api.getApiCallList api --args "sysgroup_A" systemgroup.listSystems api -A "rhel-i386-server-5,2011-04-01,2011-05-01" -F "%(name)s" \ channel.software.listAllPackages

sect2.title: clear_caches
sect2.para: Clear the internal caches kept for systems and packages

sect2.title: configchannel_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for use with configuration channels.

listitem.para: Creates a configuration file.
listitem.screen:
usage: configchannel_addfile [CHANNEL] [options]
options: -c CHANNEL -p PATH -r REVISION -o OWNER [default: root] -g GROUP [default: root] -m MODE [defualt: 0644] -x SELINUX_CONTEXT -d path is a directory -s path is a symlink -b path is a binary (or other file which needs base64 encoding) -t SYMLINK_TARGET -f local path to file contents
Note re binary/base64: Some text files, notably those containing trailing newlines, those containing ASCII escape characters (or other charaters not allowed in XML) need to be sent as binary (-b). Some effort is made to auto- detect files which require this, but you may need to explicitly specify.

listitem.para: Backup a configuration channel.
listitem.screen:
usage: configchannel_backup CHANNEL [OUTDIR]
OUTDIR defaults to $HOME/spacecmd-backup/configchannel/YYYY-MM-DD/CHANNEL

listitem.para: Clone configuration channel(s).
listitem.screen:
usage examples: configchannel_clone foo_label -c bar_label configchannel_clone foo_label1 foo_label2 -c prefix configchannel_clone foo_label -x "s/foo/bar" configchannel_clone foo_label1 foo_label2 -x "s/foo/bar"
options: -c CLONE_LABEL : name/label of the resulting cc (note does not update description, see -x option), treated as a prefix if multiple keys are passed -x "s/foo/bar" : Optional regex replacement, replaces foo with bar in the clone name, label and description Note : If no -c or -x option is specified, interactive is assumed

listitem.para: Create a configuration channel.
listitem.screen:
usage: configchannel_create [options]
options: -n NAME -l LABEL -d DESCRIPTION

listitem.para: Delete a configuration channel.
Show the details of a configuration channel.
Find differences between configuration channels.
Export configuration channel(s) to a json formatted file.
listitem.screen:
usage: configchannel_export <CHANNEL>... [options] options: -f outfile.json : specify an output filename, defaults to <CHANNEL>.json if exporting a single channel, ccs.json for multiple channels, or cc_all.json if no CHANNEL specified e.g (export ALL)
Note : CHANNEL list is optional, default is to export ALL

listitem.para: Show the details of a file in a configuration channel.
Forces a redeployment of files within a channel on all subscribed systems.
Import configuration channel(s) from a json file.
List all configuration channels.
List all files in a configuration channel.
List all systems subscribed to a configuration channel.
Remove configuration files.
Sync configuration files between two configuration channels.
Update a configuration file.
Verify a configuration file.
listitem.screen:
usage: configchannel_verifyfile CHANNEL FILE <SYSTEMS>
<SYSTEMS> may be substituted with any of the following targets: name ssm (see 'help ssm') search:QUERY (see 'help system_search') group:GROUP channel:CHANNEL

sect2.title: cryptokey_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for use with cryptographic keys.

listitem.para: Create a cryptographic key.
listitem.screen:
usage: cryptokey_create [options]
options: -t GPG or SSL -d DESCRIPTION -f KEY_FILE

listitem.para: Delete a cryptographic key.
Show the contents of a cryptographic key.
List all cryptographic keys (SSL, GPG).

sect2.title: custominfo_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for working with custom keys.

listitem.para: Create a custom key.
Delete a custom key.
Show the details of a custom key.
List all custom keys.
Update a custom key.

sect2.title: distribution_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for working with kickstart distributions.

listitem.para: Create a Kickstart tree.
listitem.screen:
usage: distribution_create [options]
options: -n NAME -p path to tree -b base channel to associate with -t install type [fedora|rhel_4/5/6|suse|generic_rpm]

listitem.para: Delete a Kickstart tree.
Show the details of a Kickstart tree.
List the available autoinstall trees.
Rename a Kickstart tree.
Update the path of a Kickstart tree.
listitem.screen:
usage: distribution_update NAME [options]
options: -p path to tree -b base channel to associate with -t install type [fedora|rhel_4/5/6|suse|generic_rpm]

sect2.title: errata_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for use with errata data.

listitem.para: Apply an patch to all affected systems.
Delete an patch.
Show the details of an patch.
List errata addressing a CVE.
List all patches.
List of systems affected by an patch.
List of CVEs addressed by an patch.
Publish an patch to a channel.
List patches that meet user provided criteria
listitem.screen:
usage: errata_search CVE|RHSA|RHBA|RHEA|CLA ...
Example: > errata_search CVE-2009:1674 > errata_search RHSA-2009:1674

listitem.para: Print a summary of all errata.

sect2.title: filepreservation_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd commands are available for working with kickstart file preservation lists.

listitem.para: Create a file preservation list.
Delete a file preservation list.
Show the details of a file preservation list.
List all file preservations.
Display the API version of the server.
Print the expiration date of the server's entitlement certificate.
Display SUSE Manager server version.
Show the current session string.
Add systems to a group.
listitem.screen:
usage: group_addsystems GROUP <SYSTEMS>
<SYSTEMS> can be any of the following: name ssm (see 'help ssm') search:QUERY (see 'help system_search') group:GROUP channel:CHANNEL

listitem.para: Backup a system group.
listitem.screen:
usage: group_backup NAME [OUTDIR]
OUTDIR defaults to $HOME/spacecmd-backup/group/YYYY-MM-DD/NAME

listitem.para: Create a system group.
Delete a system group.
Show the details of a system group.
List available system groups.
List the members of a group.
Remove systems from a group.
listitem.screen:
usage: group_removesystems GROUP <SYSTEMS>
<SYSTEMS> can be any of the following: name ssm (see 'help ssm') search:QUERY (see 'help system_search') group:GROUP channel:CHANNEL

listitem.para: Restore a system group.

sect2.remark: Add link to this section from intro for an overview of commands.

sect2.title: history
sect2.para: List recent commands using the history command.
sect2.screen: spacecmd {SSM:0}> history 1 help 2 api 3 exit 4 help 5 time --help 6 quit 7 clear spacecmd {SSM:0}>

sect2.title: kickstart_
sect2.para: The following spacecmd functions are available for use with kickstart.

listitem.para: Add activation keys to a Kickstart profile.
Add a child channels to a Kickstart profile.
Add cryptography keys to a Kickstart profile.
Add file preservations to a Kickstart profile.
Set an option for a Kickstart profile.
Add packages to a Kickstart profile.
Add a script to a Kickstart profile.
listitem.screen:
usage: kickstart_addscript PROFILE [options]
options: -p PROFILE -e EXECUTION_TIME ['pre', 'post'] -i INTERPRETER -f FILE -c execute in a chroot environment -t ENABLING_TEMPLATING

listitem.para: Add a variable to a Kickstart profile.
Clone a Kickstart profile.
Create a Kickstart profile.
listitem.screen:
usage: kickstart_create [options]
options: -n NAME -d DISTRIBUTION -p ROOT_PASSWORD -v VIRT_TYPE ['none', 'para_host', 'qemu', 'xenfv', 'xenpv']

listitem.para: Delete kickstart profile(s).
listitem.screen: usage: kickstart_delete PROFILE usage: kickstart_delete PROFILE1 PROFILE2 usage: kickstart_delete "PROF*"

listitem.para: Show the details of a Kickstart profile.
List differences between two kickstart files.
Disable configuration management on a Kickstart profile.
Disable remote commands on a Kickstart profile.
Enable configuration management on a Kickstart profile.
Enable logging for a Kickstart profile.
Enable remote commands on a Kickstart profile.
Export kickstart profile(s) to json formatted file.
listitem.screen:
usage: kickstart_export <KSPROFILE>... [options] options: -f outfile.json : specify an output filename, defaults to <KSPROFILE>.json if exporting a single kickstart, profiles.json for multiple kickstarts, or ks_all.json if no KSPROFILE specified e.g (export ALL)
Note : KSPROFILE list is optional, default is to export ALL

listitem.para: Show the contents of a Kickstart profile as they would be presented to a client.
Gets kickstart profile software details.
listitem.screen: usage: kickstart_getsoftwaredetails KS_LABEL usage: kickstart_getsoftwaredetails KS_LABEL KS_LABEL2 ...

listitem.para: Get the update type for a kickstart profile(s).
listitem.screen: usage: kickstart_getupdatetype PROFILE usage: kickstart_getupdatetype PROFILE1 PROFILE2 usage: kickstart_getupdatetype "PROF*"

listitem.para: Import a Kickstart profile from a file.
listitem.screen:
usage: kickstart_import [options]
options: -f FILE -n NAME -d DISTRIBUTION -v VIRT_TYPE ['none', 'para_host', 'qemu', 'xenfv', 'xenpv']

listitem.para: Import a raw Kickstart or autoyast profile from a file.
listitem.screen:
usage: kickstart_import_raw [options]
options: -f FILE -n NAME -d DISTRIBUTION -v VIRT_TYPE ['none', 'para_host', 'qemu', 'xenfv', 'xenpv']

listitem.para: Import kickstart profile(s) from json file.
List the available Kickstart profiles.
List the activation keys associated with a Kickstart profile.
List the child channels of a Kickstart profile.
List the crypto keys associated with a Kickstart profile.
List the custom options of a Kickstart profile.
List the options of a Kickstart profile.
List the packages for a Kickstart profile.
List the scripts for a Kickstart profile.
List the variables of a Kickstart profile.
